results.title: Food preservation
results.creator_credit: Cammell Hudson, Unilever Films and Hugh Hudson
results.brief_description: Discusses modern developments in food preservation, including quick-freezing and canning. Also shows by animation and microphotography the growth and decay of cells, and the effect of bacterial action in the cell breakdown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cammell Hudson, Unilever Films and Hugh Hudson

results.title: Food or famine
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit, Stuart Legg, Martha Varley and Alvin Bailey
results.brief_description: One-half of the human population is either underfed or malnourished; every year 50 million mouths are added to the world’s population, yet only one-tenth of the earth’s surface is farmed. Food production must be increased by using improved strains of crops, chemicals, land reclamation and better methods of fishing, plus research into hydroponics - growing crops in water with the necessary chemicals added which are present naturally in the soil.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shell Film Unit, Stuart Legg, Martha Varley and Alvin Bailey

results.title: Food of Southeast Asia
results.brief_description: Follows the activities of the children of three families to show how fish, rice and vegetables - the main foods of Southeast Asia - are produced. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Food handling
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit and Kathleen O'Brien
results.brief_description: Contrasts the healthy interior of a clean restaurant with the conditions of a careless eating-house. Shows the use of mechanised handling of food and stainless steel containers for hygiene.

results.title: Food gathering
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Records how the Waika and Makiritare Indians of South America gather some of their food from the jungle. Includes catching of snakes, fish and worms and their preparation for eating and the collection of leaves which are beaten and mashed and used ingeniously to catch fish. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Food from the sun
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Thomas Smith
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Life Science”.
Uses demonstrations and animated drawings to show how all life on earth relies on the sun for energy. Explains the process of photosynthesis. Suitable for middle primary level.

results.title: Food from the reluctant earth
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Lesley Hammond and Edwin Scragg
results.brief_description: Examines the cereal belt area of South Australia, where farmers must grow crops without irrigation and maintain livestock with a minimum of water. Explains the wheat/legume rotation system that enables farmers to obtain high yields.
results.creator_credit_for_label: South Australian Film Corporation, Lesley Hammond and Edwin Scragg

results.title: Food for thought
results.creator_credit: UNICEF, Indian Film Unit, K Khandpur and T.A. Abraham
results.brief_description: This prize-winning film illustrates the problems of the rural community of Orissa as it strives to combat hunger and malnutrition by use of improved methods of poultry and fish farming, cultivation of school gardens and nutrition education.

results.title: Food for thought
results.creator_credit: Century II Motion Pictures, Christopher Tate, Gerald Wilson, Michel Laloride and R. Ronald Brown
